note.body:
Didn't this issue went a little too far?.. It would be great add events to the calendar without being forced to edit them right after the creation just to add the hour. It sounds to me like a super common use case - I mean, doesn't most of our events last less than a day? And why would NLP be required to merely allow input such as "4pm Dinner" "4h30 Dinner" and "16:00 Dinner". Wouldn't this be possible if we make it a little simpler, and it will still be tremendously useful?

Would you accept such a thing (again, no NLP, just a time parser) as PR?

push_data.commit_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection
mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
Thanks for your comment.

With the ucm, the pulseaudio will put [In] or [Out] prefix in the port name, that is different from the names without ucm. So we couldn't change the port names in the ucm to make them be same as the ones without ucm.

Because only Dell laptops have multi-function audio jacks, we (Intel, Dell and Canonical) tested this change on different Dell laptops, include old laptops (without ucm) and recently released laptops (with ucm): Inspiron5490 Inspiron5590 Vostro5490 Vostro5590 Inspiron3590

We applied this patch to the gnome-settings-daemon, then built the whole gnome-settings-daemon, after that we ran gsd-media-keys, after we plug something in the audio jack, the pop-up dialogue will show, we could select the headphones, headset-mic or headphone-mic from the dialogue, after selecting, we could open the gnome-sound-setting to check, all audio function worked well.

Without this patch, if we plug something in the audio jack on the machines which use the ucm, the pop-up dialogue will not show up.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
This is the original design of pulseaudio, the naming rule for ucm ports was introduced by this patch: https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/pulseaudio/pulseaudio/commit/c19d1082192312bdc8fb8f8a462e2e6843efc9b6

The ucm ports and non-ucm ports have different naming rule in the pulseaudio, that exists for a long time. In the past, the ucm is used for embedded systems which have I2S codec, while the non-ucm is used for PC or laptops which have HDA codec, so the different naming rule didn't introduce any trouble. Now intel introduces the new audio driver sof which is used for HDA codec+DMIC on PCH, Intel decides to use ucm+pulseaudio. To support ucm audio functions under gnome, I wrote this patch.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body: Those names are not constant, it partly depends on the ucm, it partly depends on pulseaudio itself. For example, users put Speakers in the ucm, the finial port name is "[Out] Speakers", if users put spk in the ucm, the finial port name is "[Out] spk". Intel already finished the ucm, According to that ucm, I wrote those port names in my patch.

Countries and regions that require visa to travel to México

Valid since november 9 of 2012

People with nationalities of the following countries or regions have to obtain a visa to travel to México. For recreation, business or any type of non-paid activity in México that does not exceed 180 days, they will have to apply in a mexican council for the visitant Visa without permit to perform paid activities.

The foreign that presents any of the following documents will NOT have to apply for a visa:

a) Document that accredits a permanent residence in Canada, United States of America, Japan, United Kingdom of Great Britan and North Ireland, any of th countries that integrate the Schengen Area, and those countries that are members of the Pacific Alliance(Chile, Colombia and Peru).

events.target_title: First export to PDF resets image print definition

note.body:
Actually, the bug is not always reproducible, as can be seen on the initial question's comments on Graphic Design Stack Exchange. It happens on Manjaro KDE 18.1.3, but does not happen on Windows 10.

Also, reproduction steps as listed above are incorrect :
1. `File` => `New` and create an `A4 (300 ppi)` image using the `Template` drop down menu
2. Modify the image in any way (the image ***has*** to be modified)
3. `File` => `Export` as and export as PDF (***without*** opening the `Image` => `Print size` dialogue window and changing the ppi)

Expected :

4. The generated PDF properties should show a `Page size` of `210 x 297 mm (Portrait A4)`

Actual :

4. The generated PDF properties show a `Page size` of `875 x 1238 mm (Portrait Custom)`

Work around :

Before exporting, go to `Image` => `Print size` and change the ppi value to 300.

note.body:
The workaround posted by brianmercer resolved the issue on RHEL 7.5 modifying the .service files. For anyone else that stumbles upon this, the location is slightly different on Red Hat, /usr/share/dbus-1/services/ : 


```
/usr/share/dbus-1/services/org.gnome.Identity.service

[D-BUS Service]
Name=org.gnome.Identity
Exec=/bin/false
 
and 
 
/usr/share/dbus-1/services/org.gnome.OnlineAccounts.service

[D-BUS Service]
Name=org.gnome.OnlineAccounts
Exec=/bin/false

reboot
```

Thanks for your help! No longer have to deal with the messages log being spammed with thousands of errors a minute.

events.target_title: Consistently crashes on Passwords > Login keyring

note.body:
If this helps, I can prevent it from crashing if I use GTK_DEBUG=no-pixel-cache OR GDK_RENDERING=recording with some caveats.

GDK_RENDERING=recording works but has lots of rendering artifacts.
GDK_RENDERING=image does not crash but Passwords/Login does not render.  Certificates/Secure Shell/PGP Keys render fine.

If I use GTK_DEBUG=no-pixel-cache everything seems to work properly.

I agree with the above that it seems related to the number of passwords in the Login store.  I have 716 secrets stored in Login at the moment.

Update:  I went through my keystore and deleted a bunch of old junk.  seahorse started working again without GTK_DEBUG=no-pixel-cache somewhere between 545-538 passwords stored.  I was expecting it to fail until I got to 512 but that doesn't seem to be the case.  I would guess it has to do more with the total amount of information stored rather than the actual count of passwords.

Update 2: I see the file size of the keyring with 538 passwords is 1307914k.  I didn't check the size beforehand.

Today I checked an installation on another PC where Gimp was installed a few weeks ago (fresh install, no upgrade), and it had the same problem. events.target_title: toolbox icons lost their colors
toolbox icons lost their colors

note.body: Please don't repeat closing a bug that has not been fixed yet. How can you claim that the default theme is not broken when my screenshot proves it is? And what do you mean by "the packager"? One of my two installations is on a Windows system, with the binary installer directly downloaded from www.gimp.org. The other installation is from the FreeBSD port which simply installs what comes with the source tarball from one of the Gimp mirrors. The FreeBSD installer does not fiddle with the themes.

events.target_title: toolbox icons lost their colors
toolbox icons lost their colors

note.body:
The screenshot is from FreeBSD, but in Windows it looked the same except for the window decoration. You can easily reproduce it by doing a fresh install (unless it has been fixed in 2.10.14, which I haven't tested yet).

You can browse the FreeBSD port at https://svnweb.freebsd.org/ports/head/graphics/gimp-app/ and see that nobody made it load a certain theme. The port is just a framework to install what's in the source tarball.

Apart from that, default themes should be ignored when upgrading Gimp and an existing config is found. I have been using Gimp for years on my FreeBSD box. There are directories called $HOME/.gimp-2.4, $HOME/.gimp-2.6 and $HOME/.gimp-2.8. (Where .gimp-2.10 has gone, I don't know.) When gimp 2.10 first starts, it should read the settings from $HOME/.gimp-2.8 and use the same settings, or settings as close as possible, in the new version. That is, if the old version had colored icons, the new version should, of course, also use colored icons, even if the default for a fresh install would be grayscale icons.

events.target_title: Give/record helpful feedback if a drag & drop action fails
Give/record helpful feedback if a drag & drop action fails

note.body:
I'm afraid I don't understand enough about the working of Nautilus to know what information is made available between it and application XYZ when dragging and dropping, sorry.

I assumed it's enough to tell Nautilus the operation worked (leading to the icon disappearing over its destination) or it didn't (leading to the icon animating its returning to the Nautilus window). I hadn't considered this might be managed by something else entirely instead.

I'd hoped (naively) whatever detected these two states also received information from app XYZ in the event of an unsuccessful drop, and Nautilus might record/present that somehow. In hindsight I appreciate the responsibility for reporting a drop failure could also fall to XYZ as the destination; I thought the metaphor of dragging something *from* Nautilus *to* XYZ lent itself to logging some sort of "Nautilus couldn't do that because [x]."

events.target_title: Give/record helpful feedback if a drag & drop action fails

note.body:
That's very true. The animation makes very clear that the drop failed, yes; though in cases where this behaviour is unexpected (e.g. "It worked before, why doesn't it work now?"), the animation alone provides no context about why the drop failed.

I completely agree for cases where "We don't know anything else" is the full extent of Nautilus' understanding, another dialog to click away would be useless and annoying clutter. I'd hoped the other windows already provided information on why a drop wasn't accepted, such that Nautilus could know more and log it. If that information isn't provided, either by the other window or whatever application handles the dragging and dropping, I'm not sure how unexpected changes in drag-and-drop behaviour might be investigated further.

For example, I used to be able to drag a .png into GIMP to add it as a new layer. Recently, GIMP is now refusing the drop. Is there any information during the dragging-and-dropping process which could be logged to help investigate what's causing such behaviour? If not, is it feasible there could be?

Trial and error seems to indicate my case was caused by a mutter update, but it would have been great to have an error message logged somewhere which could have narrowed my searching online.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
Perhaps, it might be nice to have abstraction aliases (links, additional names) for PA ports so the apps can select the port according the functionality. So, for UCM the implementation in PA might be: 
analog-input-internal-mic -> [In] InternalMic
analog-input-internal-mic -> [In] DigitalMic
analog-input-internal-mic -> [In] Mic
The first present UCM device with the highest priority will win. Also, unrelated, the current gvc-mixer-control code sets analog-output-headphones for both GVC_HEADSET_PORT_CHOICE_HEADPHONES and GVC_HEADSET_PORT_CHOICE_HEADSET. This mapping should be also hidden in PA, I think. The things are worse when I look to the UCM device names for some old Intel hardware. We are too much benevolent and we need to resolve this in UCM, too. I'm talking about something like "IN1-InternalMics".

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body: Thinking more, I can add this functionality identificator to UCM device defitions, too. So the apps can group the UCM devices by the functionality and priority and choose the right one. Let me know, if you think that it's a good idea to have this description at one place (UCM).

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
Thinking more about this today, we should be probably more strict for names in UCM. The name should express the expected functionality, too.

https://github.com/alsa-project/alsa-lib/blob/5473c5d677915b88d5c93d5bcc6cd16bb6a40342/include/use-case.h#L124-L134

From the user perspective, microphone is just microphone. It does not matter, if it's analog or digital (the "visible" functionality is same). Thus names like "Dmic" or "DigitalMic" are something extra beyond a convention which we want to define. We can show this extra description using the device's comment.

I was thinking also about HeadsetMic / HeadphonesMic and I'd like to remove those names, too. The Headphones/Headset devices in UCM may be bidirectional (input + output), thus we don't need extra names for single directions.

So I just propose to follow the original names with the numbers extension (for the multiple devices like HDMI). Check the URL above, please.

I plan to write an UCM validator to check and fix all those non-standard UCM configurations.

note.body:
Thanks for the reply. Well, that is embarrassing. I only looked at the news page and the `stable` source directory, both of which are very old. Apologies.

I did actually get a bit further after hacking that function and I hit another problem where the list of files to `status` was so long that it exceeded the maximum command length. It looks like you are walking the filesystem and collecting every non-CVS file you see rather than interrogating the entries files. We have an already very large repository, that is also full of build artifacts (I know...), so there's an enormous number of files in our cvsroot directory and most of them are irrelevant. I'm thinking that even once I split the status operation up into smaller chunks, it's going to run incredibly slowly. What do you think? Roughly what size repository do you work with? Do you have any non-source controlled files under your cvsroot directory? With our in-house cvs tooling we've always had to use the various entries files to get around these issues.

events.target_title: Gimp 2.10 crashing on Lubuntu

note.body:
Setting `export SWT_GTK3=0` in  `/etc/bash.bashrc` forces GTK2 and fixes several application stability issues in Lubuntu.

Qt was deliberately designed to replace GTK3. Lubuntu ships with Qt-based LXDE, but has GTK3 enabled by default - possibly inherited from Debian.

events.target_title: window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window

note.body:
This is driving me nuts as well. I find about half the time I switch focus I accidentally type into the wrong window.

The gsetting command above has no effect however :(

events.target_title: window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window

note.body:
It looks like this is what's needed now to get responsive focus:
```
gsettings set org.gnome.shell.extensions.classic-overrides focus-change-on-pointer-rest false
```
It's astonishing how much of a difference this makes. The whole UI feels snappier when you get instantaneous feedback from common operations and moving the mouse is sadly one of the commonest. Inserting a noticeable lag to responding to mouse movements made the whole desktop feel like molasses.

A lot of the misdirected keystrokes I had were copy and pastes where I was trying to copy and paste between windows. Or where I was just trying to hit enter in the a terminal on a command that was already typed. I don't think waiting until the mouse stops moving is really a workable solution to this problem. I think you have to rethink the idea of having menus for a one window be in a separate window in a different part of the desktop such that users need to move the mouse across large distances and unrelated windows to access. That's fundamentally a broken design.

If you do want to have that perhaps you can make this menu bar have a delay or something, but please don't change the global focus behaviour just so that this menu bar does what you're looking for. I think that's the kind of thing the expression "the tail wagging the dog" was made for.

events.target_title: window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window

note.body:
Incidentally a side effect is that the response to moving the mouse is now actually *accurate*. That is, now windows are decorated and things are coloured based on where the keystrokes are actually going to be delivered. Previously there was a window of time when desktop windows were telling me they were active and would receive keystrokes but actually by the time I pressed a key that might or might not still be true.

Responsive UIs that give users accurate and reliable feedback on what the results of their actions will be are soooo much easier to use....

But that might be why some versions one is the right setting, and on other versions the other. And it may depend on whether your distribution sets an override or not.

events.target_title: text rendering requires restart to detect new fonts

note.body:
Ok, thanks. That's a lot of resources and helps clarify how other apps handle this.

So, setting the default font map to null with `pango_cairo_font_map_set_default` should force it to get a new version next time it goes to retrieve the default fontmap. So far I have added that to render_cairo_sub and I am currently working on loading a fresh version of the fontmap with fontconfig.

events.target_title: text rendering requires restart to detect new fonts

note.body:
Doesn't seem like just clearing the default and forcing a new version to be created is doing the trick for us.

I also tried the `pango::FontMapExt::changed(&font_map);` method which ends up calling `pango_fc_font_map_changed` (an apparent red herring for `pango_fc_font_map_config_changed`) which does a whole lot of nothing:

https://github.com/GNOME/pango/blob/mainline/pango/pangofc-fontmap.c#L2001

If I can get hold of someone with understanding of pango that can explain to me if there is or is not a higher level function like change that actually calls pango_fc_font_map_config_changed or why change doesn't call it, that might be the place to fix it. 

Alternatively, why nulling the default config is not reloading the cache:

```
unsafe {
        pango_cairo_sys::pango_cairo_font_map_set_default(ptr::null_mut());
    }
```

Doesn't seem to do anything even though it causes a new font_map to be created on the next call to get_default().

events.target_title: pangocairo clear font cache
pangocairo clear font cache

note.body: Ok, I added that call to the gir, regenerated and am now calling it, but it doesn't seem to do anything. Is fontconfig doing some caching as well. Even after running `fc-cache -rv`, then calling `pango_fc_font_map_config_changed` and `pango_fc_font_map_cache_clear` for good measure I'm still left with a stale cache. Application restart fixes still required. Maybe exposing `pango_fc_font_map_get_config ()` and `pango_fc_font_map_set_config ()` and then somehow using fontconfig to really flush the cache is what it takes. Or maybe it is not enough to flush the cache on a os-level, it needs to be flushed in the app as well?

events.target_title: pangocairo clear font cache

note.body:
Digging a little deeper I'm seeing that the font_map fini and init functions are clearing the local queues, but they don't touch the FcConfig object stored in `fcfontmap->priv->config`. Although, I don't quite understand the macro magic happening here in `font_map_init`:
```
priv = fcfontmap->priv = pango_fc_font_map_get_instance_private (fcfontmap);
```
Is it just getting a cached private instance? That would explain why clearing the font_map cache does nothing.

fini, inint:
https://github.com/GNOME/pango/blob/mainline/pango/pangofc-fontmap.c#L1171

Hi.

I am still seeing this problem in Evince 3.18.2-1 in Ubuntu 16 and 3.28.4 on Ubuntu 18.

Steps to reproduce the problem:
```console
$ mkdir test
$ cd test/
$ chgrp www-data .
$ chmod g+w
$ chmod g+s
$ setfacl -dm u::rwx,g::rwx,o::r  .
$ mkdir test
$ cd test/
$ chgrp www-data .
$ chmod g+w
$ chmod g+s
$ setfacl -dm u::rwx,g::rwx,o::r  .
```

Then, save file from gedit, and check permissions:
```console
-rw-rw-r--   1 administrador www-data         10 dic  5 13:07 gedit_file
```

Now, save file from Evince, and check:
```console
-rw-------   1 administrador administrador 39952 dic  4 12:52 evince_file.pdf
```

events.target_title: Gimp freezes on every attempt to Export

note.body:
I have a similar issue. I'm running OSx 10.13.6. I have reproduced this bug on every version of Gimp 2.10.x but I currently have Gimp 2.10.14 installed.  When you try to export and also when you try to do some other activities like use the file picker, Gimp freezes up. You get the spinning color wheel and it shows in the activity monitor that Gimp is not responding. If I revert back to the last version of Gimp 2.8, the issue disappears. 

As I was playing with this last night, I noticed a few things. I was testing just by dragging and dropping a .png image and then trying to export it without any editing. At some point, I decided to try some different images, and realized that the bug disappears when uploading certain other images (both .png and .svg). Very weird. I then just tried adding some text and exporting it and I still experienced the same bug.

This morning, as I was trying to reproduce the bug on Gimp 2.10.14 for the purpose of capturing the verbose output, I realized that Gimp does actually recover from this. On some exports it has recovered in as quickly as 20 seconds. On file picking actions I have clocked times of around 3 minutes. 


I am posting the verbose output below of the following actions:

1) I ran  /Applications/Gimp-2.10.app/Contents/MacOS/gimp --verbose --console-messages from terminal

2) I selected "open" from file menu and opened my downloads folder from the file picker. When I selected the download folder and clicked open, Gimp froze for 2mins 48seconds.

3) I then selected a .png image and it opened and displayed on the canvas immediately.

4) I used the paintbrush tool to draw a line on the image. 

5) I selected "export as" from the file menu and Gimp froze again for 1min 17seconds.  

6) From there I was able to rename the file and export it successfully.

events.target_title: Evolution 3.34.2 flatpak mail setting "browser-close-on-delete-or-junk" not working?
Evolution 3.34.2 flatpak mail setting "browser-close-on-delete-or-junk" not working?

note.body:
I've solved the problem. According to https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=794832 and https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=220999#c19, the command to set the option was

```gsettings set org.gnome.evolution.mail browser-close-on-delete-or-junk true```

When I run that, I receive a `No such schema “org.gnome.evolution.mail”` message.  If I instead run

```dconf write /org/gnome/evolution/mail/browser-close-on-delete-or-junk true```

the application behaves as expected.

__Case 1__: imports both documents by setting the id to the current date, the second one gets `_1` appended, but their names are identical

paperwork-shell import document*.pdf

__Case 2__: fails to import on of the document because of concurrency problems

paperwork-shell import document1.pdf & paperwork-shell import document2.pdf

__Case 3__: imports both documents as `20191207`, the second one gets `_1` appended

paperwork-shell import document1.pdf -- --name 20191207

events.target_title: Allow creation of event with start and end in different timezones

note.body:
I didn't look in bugzilla. I did look for anything similar in the Gnome issue database: I found several issues relating to Evolution having problems importing an ical file with different time zones for the start and end of an event. I think this is a different issue: I don't care how the event is represented internally or in an exported or imported ical file. I do want to be able to interactively create an event by specifying start and end times in different time zones.
One possible way of enabling this would be to switch (or make user configurable or a popup query) the way that Evolution behaves if I change the time zone after I have input a time. Currently it leaves the displayed time the same (which changes the meaning in UTC). I would like to be able to preserve the UTC time (which would change the displayed time).
An alternative would be to move the time zone to the right of the time rather than below it and have separate time zones for start and end. This needs a reasonably wide window.

note.body:
Hello!

NOTE: This email is posted to two different mail lists, due to their
relevance. Please 'reply-all' so that members of both mail lists can
follow up with the discussion.

I forgot to mention how to reproduce the issue.

1) Set up Guix System using a system configuration similar to
https://bin.disroot.org/?510c2d858eb869e9#Ef9L5uG3TBiGspwp1X3kebFSoqPWi5XSvzNdisD3V8QY
2) Login into gnome-session via gdm.
3) Install and open ungoogled-chromium.
4) Visit for example https://einthusan.ca (can be accessed only from
CA, so may need a VPN server at CA) --> Movies --> Any Language --> Any
Movie. Play the video.
5) You will see desktop stuttering right away or within few minutes.
6) Reboot system.
7) Login into i3-wm session via gdm.
8) Repeat step 3 and 4. You will not encounter desktop stuttering.

Regards,
RG.

events.target_title: Peer DNS Does not work with OpenFortiVPN 1.11

note.body:
Actually, the issue is that --no-dns is passed to openfortivpn and the default in earlier versions was pppd-use-peerdns = 1, which caused that pppd took care about the nameserver update. It was a long standing issue that openfortivpn and pppd were competing about the task to update resolv.conf. Now that we have finally found the root cause why set-dns didn't work independently from pppd, we could change the defaults. 
The only thing we didn't expect was that the network manager plugin explicitly adds --no-dns when it expects that the dns servers are updated in resolv.conf

events.target_title: Peer DNS Does not work with OpenFortiVPN 1.11

note.body:
I should have added that the more compatible change would be to add --use-peer-dns=1 to the options. That works with older versions of openfortivpn and it restores the previous behavior for the 1.11 version. 
However, a drawback is that pppd doesn't recieve the dns suffix which is added as a domain search entry in resolv.conf.
On the current master we also have support for [resolvconf](http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/trusty/man8/resolvconf.8.html). which also works with the built-in mechanism to update the nameservers.
Of course pppd can call resolvconf out of its ip-up-script, too, but again, this can only update the nameservers and not the domain search path.

Software caused connection abort, with Ubuntu
Software caused connection abort, with Ubuntu

note.body:
Issue is 100% reproducible. I am using Ubuntu 19.10 (but didn't work with recent previous Ubuntu versions either, as noted) and package manager suggests gvfs package version (and that of all other packages with name containing gvfs) is `1.42.1-1ubuntu1`

OK, I'm assuming that someone can configure a Linux server computer to make directories available via the SMB protocol (Samba).

On the client at the shell prompt

`gio mount smb://user@host/share`

where user, host and share are replaced by the appropriate values - and you enter the correct password when prompted.

This always works fine. Has worked for some time and works now.

Now launch nautilus. The mounted share shows on the left hand pane. (Good)

Single click the share. The top level directories of the share are listed in the right hand pane. (Good)

On the right hand pane navigate to a directory that contains a range of .txt files (work with me). In order that you and I can guarantee to have the same files I am going to use RFCs, which you can access by searching by RFC number here: https://www.rfc-editor.org/search/rfc_search.php

choose the ASCII version and then save as a .txt files in your share. Once you have downloaded them:

Double click the file for RFC 0792. Works fine. gedit opens and I am looking at the specification for ICMP.

Double click the file for RFC 0793 and you get the previously mentioned error from gedit
`Unexpected error: Software caused connection abort`
Expected outcome is that I am looking at the specification for TCP.

Now single click the file for RFC 0792 and press CTRL/C and then press CTRL/V

Gives error dialog `Software caused connection abort` so click Cancel
Expected outcome is no error message.

Now press F5 and you can see that the copy seems to have worked.

events.target_title: Software caused connection abort, with Ubuntu

note.body:
If launching gedit from the command line as e.g.

gedit smb://user@host/share/path/file.txt

where file.txt is that of RFC 0793 then in addition to the usual message, the following message is output to the terminal

`** (org.gnome.gedit:22057): WARNING **: 20:47:06.972: Hit unhandled case 0 (Software caused connection abort) in parse_error.`

whereas when file.txt is that of RFC 0792 no warning message is output to the terminal (and gedit works).

events.target_title: Software caused connection abort, with Ubuntu

note.body:
Attaching log. For background, the basic commands that I executed to interact with the VFS are

`gio mount smb://user@host/share`

`gedit smb://user@host/share/0793_TCP.txt`

`gio mount --unmount-scheme smb`

In the log, if you add up the bytes reported for GVfsJobRead it comes to 172710 which is exactly the length of my copy of that RFC.

[gvfsd.log](/uploads/9aa52ba741a37ac1d2832ef9dd02af6b/gvfsd.log)

note.body: PS Regarding the instructions for getting debug logs, I was unclear on how to restart gvfsd for _normal_ operation afterwards. Whatever the best answer is for that, it would be great if it were "Step 6" in the instructions. I'm just going to log out and log in again, for safety.

events.target_title: Software caused connection abort, with Ubuntu

note.body:
Update:

* I've applied for an account so that I can file a report of this at bugzilla.samba.org
* I found that with GVFS SMB logging enabled, the amount of information was incredible, seemingly because the SMB client wanders around the directory tree and pre-fetches or lists filenames - so I have created a new share with just the two needed demonstration files and that keeps the logging focused on what I am actually doing (while still exhibiting the problem).
* I looks like Samba is version 4.10.7 in the version of Ubuntu that I am using.
